instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> on bench which came with water damage. The only area which had slight corrosion was <CHIP>U8210</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R1355</RESISTOR>. After cleaning and refreshing this area board starts, takes 20V, trackpad clicks but board is stuck at 0,26A. There is no chime, no image, no post. 

The voltages I have measured:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13,05V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3,3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 5,1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 1,196V
<SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G_REG</SIGNAL> - 0,992V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL> - 0,995V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> - 1,8V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL> - 0V (CPU ressistance is around 6ohms)
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 0V


I have replaced <CHIP>U8210</CHIP> with the chip from donor board. Inspected every inch of the board and haven't found anu other corrosion except mentioned. Also have tried known good BIOS from this forum (clean ME) and no difference. Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message:
You've posted some voltages, but not <CHIP>U8210</CHIP> outputs; where you had corrosion.
Also you've mentioned iGPU missing voltage (which is not expected yet), but nothing about CPU core (L7210/20).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message:
I'm sorry, I was writing this post late at night and forgot about some voltages, so here are the missing ones:

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> - 1,8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> - 1,8V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5,10V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3,3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3,41V
L7210/20 - 0V

<CHIP>U8210</CHIP> voltages by pins:

1/2 - 3,3V
3 - 3,27V
4 - 5,1V
5 - 3,12V
6/7 - 5,1V
8/9 - 5,10V
10 - 10,72V
11 - GND
12 - 10,67V
13/14 - 3,3V

I forgot to mention, that after connecting charger board starts, gets stuck at 20V 0,26A, then restarts once and after that it is stuck at constant 20V 0,26A

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message:
CPU core not present, so the board is stuck; didn't complete Power On Sequence.

Do you get L7370 voltage?
Check all voltages from pages 61-64.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message: I do, voltage on L7370 is 1,049V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message: The only votlages I'm missing from the listed in schematic are <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL>. Sadly I just hav noticed, that <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G</SIGNAL> is reading 1,6ohm and <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G</SIGNAL> is 3ohm... So my guess is CPU is dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message:
"The only votlages I'm missing from the listed in schematic are <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL>."
As I already said, iGPU voltage is not expected yet; only appears when high graphics load is detected.

CPU coils have very low resistance to ground as normal; compare with good board.
However, CPU dies easy on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> machines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message: Ok, so if missing voltages are related to iGPU and every other voltage is present, it means that CPU doesn’t turn on anyway, right? <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> is 0V, so board is in reset mode. I have no idea what else could keep board in that state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message:
"every other voltage is present"
Every other no; you don't get CPU core voltage (L7210/20)!
May have BIOS issue, bad CPU, <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> problem.
This is not an exact science...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message: I have already tried another BIOS which I can confirm is good (btw. You shared it with me in another thread). I will try new <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and inspect board again for corrosion, maybe I have missed something…

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message: Unfortunatelly customer couldn't wait longer as he had to flight back to US. Thankfully, he lives in NY, so I advised him to get to Rossmann repair shop. I gave him our visit card and contact, he will give it to you while leaving computer in Rossmann repair shop. If you will need some additional info, photos and and what has been done on the computer you can contact us.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no brain/post
threads.message:
I'm based on Madrid, Spain.
Rossmann repair shop will solve the problem in US...
